Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Nanomechanics with SCC-DFTB Objective Molecular Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to understand and model the helical structure and mechanics of amyloid fibrils, and the stability and mechanical energy storage in helical zinc oxide nanostructures. Because these structures exist on a scale comparable to interatomic distances, atomistic detail is essential to understanding their behavior. The planned nanomechanical computations are prohibitive with current quantum methods, which are dependent on the translational symmetry of crystalline solids. They become possible, however, with the new objective molecular dynamics method coupled with the self-consistent-charge density-functional tight-binding. This coupling relies on a proposed generalization of the Ewald method to a helical charge distribution. Preliminary results indicate that this generalization is feasible and could enable efficient nanostructure and biomolecule simulations.

If successful, the methodology will allow for the first time the evaluation of electrostatic fields generated by discrete charge distributions over helical structures in modern materials and life sciences on a quantitative level. The amyloid fibril studies, aimed at understanding key atomistic details, mechanical properties and correlations between polymorphism and mechanical response, will help elucidate molecular mechanisms in Alzheimer's and other prion diseases. Also, they will have implications for the meso-scale modeling of amyloid fibrils and for the biomimetic development of nanomaterials. The helical zinc oxide nanobelts simulations, focused on super elasticity, buckling, fracture, and the transfer of mechanical into electric energy, will produce a phenomenological Landau model useful for designing power nano-generators. The planned research is integrated with an educational program that facilitates the incorporation of nanomechanics into the engineering curriculum; it is also accompanied by efforts to encourage participation of underrepresented minorities. A cyber-module will illustrate for the Minnesota public underlying effects related to prion diseases, and mechanisms responsible for nano-energy storage. This module will be made available to the Minnesota Science Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efforts were channeled on making possible nanomechanical studies using more accurate quantum-mechanical treatments of inter-atomic bonding. Existing atomistic modeling tools can be used to simplify simulation of structures that have translational periodicity, such as a bulk crystal or a pristine nanowire (NW) or nanotube (NT). However, many nano- and bio-structures have rotational and/or helical symmetries instead – either inherent in their structure or imposed by a deformation such as torsion. We have performed method development and computational work toward the development symmetry-adapted molecular dynamics (MD) technique termed objective molecular dynamics (OMD). In OMD, the standard translational symmetry is replaced with the objective helical and/or rotational symmetries to give significant reduction in the number of atoms that need to be simulated. The small number of atoms replicated with an arbitrary combination of rotation and translation operations, are representing an infinite helical structure that may not possess any pure translational periodicity.  We use the computational savings created by reducing the number of atoms to apply the more accurate quantum treatments of the inter-atomic interactions. 

In a first stage, we have performed the coupling of OMD with a tight-binding treatment of bonding.Thisadvance opened the possibility to simulate, based on density-functional based tight-binding (DFTB), an important class of helical nanostructures, such as twisted graphenenanoribbons [Dontsova, Dumitrică, J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 4, 2010, 2013]. Nevertheless, the DFTB level of chemistry, comprising ‘band structure’ and short-range repulsive terms fitted to density functional results has limitations. It is insufficient to tackle a much larger variety of existing most interesting helical bio- and nanostructures some containing chemical elements of rather different electronegativity. DFTB is also less adequate for describing severe mechanical deformations under which charge transfer between atoms is changing, and thus for making credible predictions of respective new materials. The self-consistent charge (SCC) DFTB level of chemistry is better suited. Therefore, ina second stage, we coupled OMD with SCC-DFTB. Because bio- and nanostructures are structured on a scale comparable to interatomic distances, atomistic detail is essential to understanding their behavior. Thus, improving the capability of atomistic simulations to describe these structures represents a significant advance. Currently, helical structures are simulated using a large number of atoms, either by artificially imposing translational periodicity, or by considering an isolated cluster. In contrast, we employ a small number of atoms replicated with an arbitrary combination of rotation and translation operations, representing an infinite helical structure that may not possess any pure translational periodicity.

Our SCC DFTB - OMD coupling utilizes a generalized Ewald summation numerical approach. When Paul Peter Ewald penned his summation method in 1921, it is unlikely that he would have foreseen the use of computers to simulate crystals at the atomistic level, let alone the impact of his method on this field. Ewald summation is essential to many atomistic simulation techniques and has enabled countless discoveries of material properties. However, like many other atomistic tools, classical Ewald is dependent on the translational symmetry of crystalline solids.  We demonstrated that the Ewald's method can be adapted to the helical case to enable efficient nanostructure and biomolecule simulations. [Nikiforov, Hourahine, Aradi, Frauenheim, Dumitrică,J. Chem. Phys. 139, 094110, 2013.] To help deployment, the method has been integrated into the popular DFTB+ code (www.dftbplus.org).
